journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Polycaprolactone–starch blends with corn-based coupling agent: physical properties and in vitro analysis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical, Robotics, and Energy Engineering, Dongguk University, Korea
2Department of Manufacturing and Industrial Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Malaysia
3Research Institute of Biotechnology, Dongguk University, Korea
4Department of Medical Biotechnology, Dongguk University, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Denni Kurniawan, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Skudai 81310, Malaysia. Email: denni@utm.my

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on musculoskeletal modelling of the lower limb

abstract.p: In an attempt to improve properties of polycaprolcatone–starch blend, this study uses zein as coupling agent in preparing the blend through a single-step process. Zein, which has affinity to both polar and non-polar groups, is expected to improve miscibility between the blends’ constituents and its overall biocompatibility. Mechanical properties of the blend were tested and further characterizations (Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermal properties) were performed to analyze the effect of zein as an addition to the blend’s physical properties. The blend’s biocompatibility was examined by indirect methods (contact angle and weight gain after immersion in simulated body fluid) and in vitro analysis. No significant effect on the blend’s strength and stiffness was caused by adding zein. Hydrophilicity and cell affinity were improved when zein was added. Zein did not perform as a coupling agent that improved miscibility between polycaprolactone and starch, but its addition improved the blend’s biocompatibility.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polycaprolactone (PCL) is being developed as the material of scaffolds for tissue engineering.1 PCL is considered as having fair mechanical properties and characteristics of potential for load-bearing applications, including cardiovascular, dental, and musculoskeletal;1–4 yet, its implementation faces some issues, e.g. inadequate mechanical properties, bioresorbability, and hydrophilicity.1,5 A possible way, in an attempt to address these issues, is by compounding with other biocompatible materials, and starch is of interest.

Immiscibility is an issue in blending starch to PCL. It leads to deteriorating mechanical properties and may affect the blend’s overall performance. Considering the intended applications, options are limited in compatibilizing these constituents where any substance to be incorporated into the blend should also be biocompatible. Previous studies for compatibilizing PCL and starch reported the use of predried starch,6 chlorinated starch (by using methanesulfonylchloride in dimethylformamide),7 glycidyl methacrylate,8 and plasticizer.9 Attempts were also made by using harmful compatibilizing agents, e.g. methylenediphenyl diisocyanate,10 acrylic acid,11 diethyl maleate,8 and maleic anhydride.12 The use of those compatibilizing agents resulted in some improvements in the physical properties of the PCL–starch blends, but did not solve the immiscibility problem.

In a similar attempt to address the issue, this study proposes the use of zein, a prolamine protein from corn, which was also reported to be biocompatible.13,14 Zein is amphiphilic, having affinity to both polar and non-polar groups.15 Zein was used as a coupling agent for a natural fiber–thermoplastic composite and resulted in enhanced mechanical properties,16 an indication of improved miscibility between its constituents. This potential of zein as a coupling agent is expected to be exhibited for PCL–starch blends in the form of improved physical properties and compatibility with bone cells during short-term in vitro evaluation.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The PCL used was of high purity (<1% total impurity), with molecular weight, Mn, of 80,000 and density of 1.145 g/mL at 25 °C, as informed by the supplier (Aldrich, Korea). The starch used was edible corn starch consisting of 95% corn starch and 5% wheat flour, supplied by a local manufacturer. Zein was procured in the form of a yellowish powder, containing approximately 35% α-zein (Sigma).

Specimens were prepared by melt–mixing 20 grams of mixture at 120±20 °C for 8 min using Mini Max Molder (Custom Scientific Instruments) and subsequent injection molding to dies of ASTM D638 type V. The blend’s composition is denoted in Table 1.

caption.p: Composition of the blends (values shown are in wt%).

sec.title: Mechanical properties testing
sec.p: Houndsfield H5KT (Tinius Olsen, Korea), with 5 kN load cell, was used for the tensile tests. The cross-head speed for tensile testing neat PCL and its blends was 5 mm/min. Five specimens were tested for every composition.

In determining the significance of the starch and zein addition to mechanical properties, statistical analysis was used by constructing a factorial design involving two categorical variables, i.e. starch content (2 levels) and zein content (2 levels). Analysis of variance (ANOVA) of each experimental dataset was used to determine the significance of each variable, as well as possible interaction the variables. A confidence interval of 95% was set, with probabilistic value, Prob > F, of maximum 5% as the criterion for the variables to be considered significant. Calculations were conducted using statistics software (Design Expert, Stat-Ease, USA).

sec.title: Thermal characterization
sec.p: Thermal analysis was conducted using Perkin-Elmer DSC 7 differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) set for scanning from 20 °C to 80 °C at 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. The observed output was melting temperature (Tm), heat of fusion (ΔHf), and crystallinity.

sec.title: Structural characterization
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was conducted on selected samples using Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 with a KBr/Ge beam splitter. The FTIR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 600 cm−1 with 2 cm−1 resolution, averaged over 32 scans.

sec.title: Morphology characterization
sec.p: For morphology analysis, a scanning electron microscope (SEM) JEOL JSM 5800 was used.

sec.title: Hydrophylicity characterization
sec.p: To evaluate hydrophilicity, a contact angle measurement was conducted using a pendant drop tensiometer Krüss DSA100. The contact angle was measured from the interface between the specimen and the droplet of 2 μl distilled water on a specimen’s surface. Further evaluation was conducted by analyzing the blends’ tendency to absorb simulated body fluid. PCL and its blends were immersed for 24 h in a saline solution at 37±2 °C and their weight gain was measured.

sec.title: In vitro analysis
sec.p: For in vitro analysis of the blends, mesenchymal stem cells were seeded and cultured on selected samples. The mesenchymal stem cells were isolated from human bone marrow, with procedures that have been established a priori.17,18 Mononuclear cells were plated into tissue culture flasks in an expansion medium, consisting of Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM, Invitrogen, USA) and 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Cambrex, USA), at a density of 5 × 104 cells/cm2. Upon reaching 80% confluency, cells were detached with Accutase (Innovative Cell Technologies, USA) and replated at a density of approximately 1 × 104 cells/cm2. The cells were then expanded further for two to six passages. Sterilized (γ-irradiated) PCL and its blends were placed in six-well plates and inoculated with 100 μl of the harvested cell suspension at a concentration of 2 × 105 cells/100 μl by direct pipetting. The plates were incubated for 1 h in 100 μl of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS at 37 °C under 5% CO2 atmosphere. Next, the specimens were cultured with 3 ml of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS for 1 day and 14 days for the proliferation assays (n = 3).

For assessment of cell proliferation, a 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide (MTT, Sigma, Korea) assay was used, following the manufacturer’s protocol. For the MTT assay, cell-cultured specimens were transferred to a 12-well plate, and serum-free DMEM supplemented with MTT (0.33 mg/ml) was added to each well. The plates were then incubated in the dark at 37 °C in an atmosphere containing 5% CO2 for 2 h, aspirating the supernatant. Isopropyl alcohol (1 ml) containing 0.04 N HCl was added and the plate was shaken slowly for 15 min. The absorption was measured at 540 nm.

To determine whether mineralized nodules were formed on the blends, the presence of bone sialoprotein was identified. For this purpose, a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was conducted on the cultured cells.18 The products were then analyzed on 2% agarose gels and visualized by ethidium bromide staining.

For cell morphology analysis using a SEM, the cells on each specimen were fixed for 2 h in a mixture of 4% glutaraldehyde and 2% formaldehyde in a phosphate buffer (a mixture of monosodium phosphate and dipotassium phosphate, 0.2 M, pH of 7.4) at room temperature. After rinsing thoroughly with a 0.175 M phosphate buffer, the specimens were immersed in 2% osmium tetroxide buffered with 0.2 M phosphate for 2 h. The specimens were then dehydrated in hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS, Bio-Rad, UK) and gold sputter-coated.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: From the tensile test (overall results shown in Table 2), the blend’s strength reduced and its stiffness increased with a higher starch content, a common indication of immiscibility. However, it should be noted that the tendency only applies to the mean values (when standard deviation is taken into account, starch content gives no effect to the blend’s mechanical properties). The addition of zein does not affect the blend’s mechanical properties.

ANOVA for tensile strength and modulus (Table 3) unveiled that only starch content was considered significant in affecting the mechanical properties of the blend. The addition of zein was not significant enough to influence the blend’s strength and stiffness.

caption.p: ANOVA for tensile strength and modulus.

sec.p: Zein, like starch, is a relatively high modulus thermoplastic.19 Therefore, the addition of zein increases the blend’s stiffness, including when compared with that of neat PCL. Yet, yield strength of the blend decreases with the addition of zein. Considering that PCL is a good dispersant of fillers, it indicates that zein also has high mobility, causing instability within the PCL matrix when tensile loaded.

FTIR analysis on PCL, starch, zein, and the blends (Figure 1) indicated that the spectra of both PCL–starch and PCL–starch–zein blends are similar to that of neat PCL. A peak of around 1700 cm−1 for the internal ester group of the PCL within the blends was not affected by internal C—O—C bond (around 1650 cm−1) of the starch or bands of amide II (1750–1600 cm−1) of the zein.7,20 This implies that no molecular bond occurred between PCL and starch or zein.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of PCL and its blends.

sec.p: Thermal analysis (Table 4) disclosed a slight change in the melting point of the blends compared with that of neat PCL. In term of crystallinity, the addition of starch causes the blend to be less crystalline while adding zein on the blend increases its crystallinity. Higher crystallinity often relates to increased mechanical properties. In this case, although zein increases crystallinity of the PCL matrix, it does not translate to a higher strength of the blend. This means interfaces between PCL and zein do not adhere well.

caption.p: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) analysis on the blends.

sec.p: Image analysis on the blend using SEM (Figure 2) confirmed the immiscibility of starch on PCL. The zein surface partially adhered to the PCL, yet the starch and zein particles were not compounded.

caption.p: Typical cross section image of (a) PCL/S10 and (b) PCL/S10/Z.

sec.p: The contact angle of the blend decreased with more starch and zein contents (Table 5). The blend became more hydrophilic with the addition of zein, likely owing to the hydrophilic portion of its molecules.15 Immersion of the blends in a saline solution showed that higher weight gain occurred on the blends compared with neat PCL (Figure 3). This indicates better wettability when starch and zein is added to the PCL. Similar to the results shown on the blend’s surface (by contact angle measurement), simulated body fluid also penetrated the blend better with the addition of zein.

caption.p: Weight gain after 24 h immersion in saline solution at 37 °C.

sec.p: This increased hydrophilicity exhibited by the contact angle and immersion results was expected to lead to better cell affinity to the zein-added blend. Cell growth results indicated that this was the case (Figure 4). After 1 day of cell culture, the number of cells in the zein-added blend was similar to that of the PCL–starch blend. After 14 days, the advantage of adding zein to the blend was more apparent, with the increase in cell number. SEM pictures of the 14-day cultured cells on PCL and the blends (Figure 5) indicated that cells could grow well on PCL, but they grow better on the PCL–starch blend, and seemingly, the addition of zein into the blend facilitates their growth further.

caption.p: Cell growth after 1 day and 14 days.
Images of cells after 14 days of culture on (a) PCL, (b) PCL/S20, and (c) PCL/S20/Z.

sec.p: The cultured cells were also further identified by the presence of bone-related tissues on PCL and the blends. Trace of bone sialoprotein (BSP) and type I collagen on the cells were used as indicators. BSP, a highly glycosylated and sulphated phosphoprotein, is an indicator of bone mineralization.21 Presence of type I collagen, a fibrillar type that is part of the extracellular matrix,22 might also indicate the potency of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) differentiation into cartilage or bone. Results (Figure 6) showed that cells cultured on blends contained less BSP than those on neat PCL, and the addition of zein to the blend slightly improved this. Similar result was shown on the presence of type I collagen (Figure 7). It should be noted that these results were based on a single test on each blend and it may not be statistically representative. The addition of zein to the blend tended to improve the blend’s behavior for cells to generate an extracellular matrix. In itself, zein was reported to facilitate growth, proliferation, and differentiation of MSC towards osteoblast.14 Considering the intended use of the blend as a biomaterial for bone and cartilage scaffolds, the results shown by zein added to the PCL–starch blend is encouraging.

caption.p: Detected BSP in cells cultured for 14 days on the blends.
Detected type I collagen in cells cultured for 14 days on the blends.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The addition of zein to the PCL–starch blend, through a single-step process, did not cause a significant reinforcement effect. Zein did not perform well as a coupling agent owing to its partial immiscibility to the PCL matrix and it did not compound with the starch. However, in terms of hydrophilicity and cell affinity, the addition of zein enhanced the blend’s biocompatibility, likely contributed by its hydrophilic molecules portion.

ack.p: Authors acknowledge facilities provided by Professor Myung Cheon Lee (Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Dongguk University). Part of the manuscript was presented at the 18th International Conference on Composite Materials, 21–26 August 2011, Jeju Island, Korea. The authors acknowledge the Korean Society for Composite Materials, Seoul, Korea, for the use of copyrighted text and illustrations.
